awd_titl_txt: Eco-DAS 2.0:   Ecological Dissertations in the Aquatic Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
An ecological scientist's most important asset can be an extensive professional network that allows the scientist to tackle problems that could not possibly be solved alone.  The Ecological Dissertations in the Aquatic Sciences (Eco-DAS) program brings together recent recipients of doctoral degrees in any area of the ecology of water bodies: oceans, estuaries, lakes, ponds, rivers, streams, or groundwater.  The purpose of Eco-DAS is to promote collaborative science by building strong, diverse professional networks early in the careers of aquatic scientists.  

The highlight of each Eco-DAS cohort is a symposium, but participants begin working together several weeks before the symposium and continue to work together for more than a year afterward.  They begin by proposing to write articles that depend on developing an author team.  During the symposium, author teams self-organize around some of the offered topics.  By the end of the symposium, author teams have developed outlines for 10-12 manuscripts, and the manuscripts are written after the symposium.  Although even the process of developing a manuscript outline will build network connections, more than ½ of author teams continue all the way to having their article published.  All published articles generated by Eco-DAS author teams are freely available to the public. 

In addition to formation of author teams, mentor-led discussions, informative panels, and workshops are held during the symposium to prepare participants for the challenges of academic and non-academic careers in the aquatic sciences. 

The Eco-DAS 2.0 award funded three biannual symposia with a total of 110 participants, most of whom were USA residents.  The cohorts were diverse with respect to gender, ethnicity, race, and scientific specialty. Science extends beyond national borders and it’s important for a professional scientist to engage with an international network.  About 15% of participants were from outside the US and were supported primarily by $30,000 in donated funds.

In addition to interacting with one another, the participants interacted with a total of 51 mentors representing different facets of aquatic science professions.  The average Eco-DAS participant added a total of 54 new professional colleagues to their professional network. 

This award resulted in the preparation, submission, and publication of a total of 17 formal articles.  Eleven of these appeared in peer-reviewed professional publications, and six appeared in a non-reviewed professional publication read by thousands of aquatic scientists.  Collectively, the peer-reviewed articles already have been cited 320 times by other science articles.  This is an extraordinarily high publication rate and citation total from a single NSF award. 

Additionally, an Eco-DAS author team – WikiProject Limnology and Oceanography – focused on improving the representation of aquatic science on the public information website Wikipedia.org. To date, WikiProject L&O has improved hundreds of Wikipedia pages, held three workshops to teach early career scientists how to edit Wikipedia pages, and released a 54-slide presentation on Wikipedia editing for general use.  Many of the pages edited by WikiProject L&O are viewed hundreds of times every day.  The WikiProject L&O team continues to work together, as do other author teams formed during Eco-DAS 2.0. 

 


Last Modified: 06/03/2022
Modified by: Paul F Kemp

An ecological scientist's most important asset can be an extensive professional network that allows the scientist to tackle problems that could not possibly be solved alone.  The Ecological Dissertations in the Aquatic Sciences (Eco-DAS) program brings together recent recipients of doctoral degrees in any area of the ecology of water bodies: oceans, estuaries, lakes, ponds, rivers, streams, or groundwater.  The purpose of Eco-DAS is to promote collaborative science by building strong, diverse professional networks early in the careers of aquatic scientists.  

The highlight of each Eco-DAS cohort is a symposium, but participants begin working together several weeks before the symposium and continue to work together for more than a year afterward.  They begin by proposing to write articles that depend on developing an author team.  During the symposium, author teams self-organize around some of the offered topics.  By the end of the symposium, author teams have developed outlines for 10-12 manuscripts, and the manuscripts are written after the symposium.  Although even the process of developing a manuscript outline will build network connections, more than ½ of author teams continue all the way to having their article published.  All published articles generated by Eco-DAS author teams are freely available to the public. 

In addition to formation of author teams, mentor-led discussions, informative panels, and workshops are held during the symposium to prepare participants for the challenges of academic and non-academic careers in the aquatic sciences.

Science extends beyond national borders and it’s important for a professional scientist to engage with an international network.  About 15% of participants were from outside the US and were supported primarily by $30,000 in donated funds.

In addition to interacting with one another, the participants interacted with a total of 51 mentors representing different facets of aquatic science professions.  The average Eco-DAS participant added a total of 54 new professional colleagues to their professional network. 

This award resulted in the preparation, submission, and publication of a total of 17 formal articles. Additionally, an Eco-DAS author team – WikiProject Limnology and Oceanography – focused on improving the representation of aquatic science on the public information website Wikipedia.org. To date, WikiProject L&O has improved hundreds of Wikipedia pages, held three workshops to teach early career scientists how to edit Wikipedia pages, and released a 54-slide presentation on Wikipedia editing for general use.  Many of the pages edited by WikiProject L&O are viewed hundreds of times every day.  The WikiProject L&O team continues to work together, as do other author teams formed during Eco-DAS 2.0.
